title: 103_hr1616
content: The "Handgun Registration Act of 1993" requires a federal handgun registration system to apply in states without their own system meeting certain requirements. Beginning 2 years after the enactment of the "Handgun Registration Act of 1993," the Federal handgun registration system established by the Attorney General will apply in states that do not comply with the requirements of the State handgun registration system. State laws must mandate registration of handguns with a State law enforcement agency for individuals who own, possess, or control a handgun. The Handgun Registration Act of 1993 requires individuals to register handguns with a State law enforcement agency within 90 days of ownership. Penalties are imposed for violations of this registration requirement. The Handgun Registration Act of 1993 mandates registration of handguns within 90 days of ownership. Penalties for violations include imprisonment for not less than 1 year for non-serious violations and not less than 12 years for serious violations. A serious violation is defined by state law as possessing 2 or more unregistered handguns or possessing an unregistered handgun of high caliber. The Handgun Registration Act of 1993 requires registration of handguns within 90 days of ownership. Penalties for violations include imprisonment for not less than 1 year for non-serious violations and not less than 12 years for serious violations. A serious violation involves possessing 2 or more unregistered handguns or possessing an unregistered handgun of high caliber. State law must maintain an easily retrievable record of handguns and identify individuals who reside or frequently access them. To comply with the Handgun Registration Act of 1993, individuals in the State must register their handguns within 90 days of ownership if they reside or frequently appear in the State and possess, own, or control a handgun. The Handgun Registration Act of 1993 requires individuals in the State to register their handguns within 90 days of ownership if they reside or frequently appear in the State and possess, own, or control a handgun. Additionally, there is a provision for a Federal Handgun Registration System. The Attorney General will establish a Federal handgun registration system to identify residents who own, possess, or control handguns. Individuals in applicable States must register their handguns under the Handgun Registration Act of 1993. The Handgun Registration Act of 1993 requires individuals to register their handguns with law enforcement agencies or licensed dealers within 90 days of ownership. Violating this law can result in a fine of up to $250,000, a minimum 15-year imprisonment, or both. The court cannot suspend imprisonment or impose probation for such offenses. The Handgun Registration Act of 1993 mandates registering handguns with law enforcement or licensed dealers within 90 days of ownership. The amendment defines "handgun" and extends the law to the District of Columbia and U.S. territories. Effective two years after enactment, violations incur penalties of up to $250,000, a minimum 15-year imprisonment, or both, without the option of probation. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OF FEDERAL ASSISTANCE: The Attorney General will end federal assistance under certain parts of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act to states when the Federal handgun registration system is in effect. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "handgun" refers to a pistol or revolver designed to be fired with one hand using fixed cartridge ammunition. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia and U.S. territories and possessions.
